document.docAuthor: Brescovit, Antonio D. & Santos, Adalberto J.
document.masterDocTitle: The spider genus Kukulcania in South America (Araneae: Filistatidae): a redescription of K. brevipes (Keyserling) and new records of K. hibernalis (Hentz)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The spider genus Kukulcania in South America (Araneae: Filistatidae): a redescription of K. brevipes (Keyserling) and new records of K. hibernalis (Hentz)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Laboratório Especial de Coleções Zoológicas, Instituto Butantan, Av. Vital Brasil, 1500, Butantã, São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil, CEP 05503 - 900. E-mail: adbresc @ terra. com. br
Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Ciências Biológicas, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Av. Antonio Carlos, 6627. Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil. CEP 31270 - 901. E-mail: oxyopes @ yahoo. com

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Filistata brevipes
Keyserling, 1883: 221–223
(Female holotype from Peru , no other data, should be at the Museum and Institute of Zoology of the Polish Academy of Sciences ( Warsaw ), not found, probably lost).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Keyserling (1883) stated that the holotype was deposited in the collection of the “Universität in Warschau”. The material from that institution was later transferred to the Museum and Institute of Zoology of the Polish Academy of Sciences ( Kazubski 1996 ; Mlíkovský 2007 ). However, despite our efforts the type specimen could not be found in that collection (D. Mierzwa and G.S. Ruiz, pers. comm.), thus we presume it is lost. In this study, we recognize
K. brevipes
based on the original description and on the distribution of the specimens we examined. Based on published descriptions ( Cambridge 1896 , 1899 , Chamberlin & Ivie 1935 , 1942 , Alayón- García 1972 ) and the additional material examined by us (see
K. hibernalis
material examined below and Appendix 1), we are confident that the Peruvian specimens listed below are conspecific with the type of
K. brevipes
. This species is similar to other species of the genus,
K. hibernalis
in particular, in general morphology ( Ramírez & Grismado 1997 ,
Platnick et al. 1991
,
Griswold et al. 2005
) and natural history (see below).

Diagnosis .
Males of
Kukulcania brevipes
can be distinguished from other species of the genus by the presence of a pair of ventral lines of stout spines on the tibiae of palp and leg I ( Figs. 1A , 2A , 8A ). The male palp differs from other species in the presence of long and flattened setae on the apex of cymbium and in the embolus not coiled, gently sinuous ( Figs. 1A–C , 5A ). Females can be recognized by the spermathecae positioned anteriorly to the copulatory ducts ( Figs. 3A , 4 AB).

Female .
(IBSP 163503, Lima , Provincia de Cañete, Lunahuana)
. Carapace brown with cephalic area black ( Figs. 8 BC). Chelicerae black. Endites, labium and sternum orange brown. Palps brown, with femur yellowish ( Fig. 2B ). Legs brownish with longitudinal orange stripes dorsally on tibiae ( Fig. 2C ). Abdomen dorsally and laterally black, ventrally brownish ( Fig. 8 BC). Total length 10.20. Carapace length 4.5, width 3.6. Chelicerae fused at base, promarginal lamina and fang short ( Fig. 5E ). Palp measurements: femur 2.3, patella 1.4, tibia 1.4, tarsus 1.6. Palpal claw short, with 7–9 short teeth ( Fig. 6 BC). Leg measurements: I: femur 5.4/ patella 2.0/ tibia 5.0/ metatarsus 4.7/ tarsus 2.3/ total 19.40; II: 4.3/ 1.8/ 3.3/ 3.3/ 1.8/ 14.50; III: 3.3/ 1.7/ 2.5/ 2.8/ 1.6/ 11.90; IV: 4.8/ 1.9/ 4.1/ 3.8/ 1.8/ 16.40. Spines: pedipalp, femur v15-20 pairs with a basal group of 10-15, tibia v0-1-3, p1-1-3, tarsus v2-2-2-1; legs, I femur v14-16 pairs, d1-1-1, tibia v2-2-1r-2, metatarsus v2-1, r-2-2-2, p0-0-01, r0-0-1, tarsus v6-8 short pairs, p1-1-1-1 (short), r1-1-1-1 (short); II femur v14-16 pairs, d1-1-1, p1-0-0, tibia v2-2-21r-2, metatarsus v2-1, r-2-2-2, p0-0-2, r0-0-2, tarsus as leg I; III v14-16 pairs, d1-0-0, tibia v2-1, r-2-4, p0-1-1, metatarsus v2-2-2-1, p-4, p1-1-2, tarsus as in leg I; IV v14-16 pairs, d1-0-0, tibia 1p-1p-1p, metatarsus 1p-1p-4, tarsus as in leg I. Third claw curved with three long teeth ( Fig. 5F ). Calamistrum composed of 12–14 flattened setae, organized in an irregular row ( Fig. 6A ). Abdomen 6.2 long. Cribellum located in a wide sclerotized plate, cribellar spigots clubshaped, organized in two spinning fields ( Fig. 7B ). Anterior lateral spinnerets with a mesal fringe of stout setae ( Fig. 7C ), spinning field with three major ampullate gland spigots, two at the border and one inside a field with piriform gland spigots ( Fig. 7D ). Posterior median spinnerets with three large paracribellar gland spigots, with flattened apex, along with one minor ampullate gland and at least one aciniform gland spigots ( Fig. 7E ). Posterior lateral spinnerets with three large, paracribellar gland spigots at the margin of spinning field, which is covered by aciniform gland spigots ( Fig. 7F ). Spermathecae globose, hyaline dorsally and sclerotised ventrally ( Figs. 3A , 4 AB), covered with pores and, presumably, dorsal gland ducts ( Fig. 6F ). Copulatory ducts slender, covered laterally by an internal hyaline plate ( Figs. 4 AB).

Kukulcania spp. A
–C,
K. brevipes (Keyserling)
, male (IBSP 162501): A, palp, prolateral view (arrow indicates ventral spines of femur); B, cymbium and copulatory bulb, prolateral (arrow indicates flattened setae on apex of cymbium); C, ditto, retrolateral. D–F,
K. hibernalis (Hentz)
, male (IBSP 117068): D, palp, prolateral view; E, cymbium and copulatory bulb, prolateral; F, ditto, retrolateral.

FIGURES 2A–F.
Kukulcania spp. A
–C,
K. brevipes (Keyserling)
: A, male (IBSP 162501) leg I, prolateral view; B, female (IBSP 162501) palp, prolateral; C, female leg I, prolateral. D–F,
K. hibernalis (Hentz)
: D, male (IBSP 117068) leg I, prolateral view; E, female (IBSP 2607) palp, prolateral; C, female leg I, prolateral.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Natural history .
Specimens were collected in villages and rural areas in coastal Peru , always associated to buildings, walls or piles of construction debris. Females were found inside silken tubes between stones or bricks, with the tube entrance generally surrounded by a dense net of cribellar threads ( Fig. 8D ), a web structure already reported for other filistatids ( Lopardo & Ramírez 2007 ). Males were usually found wandering close to female retreats. One specimen was captured close to the entrance of a female retreat, while plucking the cribellar threads with the first leg (presumably courting the female inside – as seen in
K. hibernalis
by Barrantes & Ramírez 2013 ). Several females were collected holding spherical egg-sacs with the chelicerae and palps ( Fig. 8 BC), as described for
K. geophila
by Cokendolpher & MacDonald (2007) . A constant contact between the female and the egg-sac was also reported for
K. hibernalis
by Curtis & Carrel (1999) , though without more details. These observations suggest that maternal care is common in members of this genus, possibly even in other genera of the family (see Cokendolpher & MacDonald 2007 ).

FIGURES 4A–B.

FIGURES 5A–F.
Kukulcania brevipes (Keyserling)
, SEM images (MUSM): A, male palp, prolateral view; B, ditto, apex of flattened setae; C, male metatarsus II (arrow indicates trichobothrium); D, male palpal tibia, elongated setae; E. female chelicerae, ventral view; F, female tarsus I, claws. Scale bars: A, E, F 0.1 mm; B 0.02 mm; C, D 0.05 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution : Known from Peru and northern Chile ( Fig. 9 ).
